newsitem.title: USA: Argentine sugar crop down, exports steady-Attache.
newsitem.headline: Argentine sugar crop down, exports steady-Attache.

text.p: Argentina will produce 1.32 million tonnes of sugar in the 1997 marketing year, a sharp decrease from the previous season, but exports should remain at expected levels, the U.S. agricultural attache in Buenos Aires said in a report released Thursday.
"Exports for 1997 are still estimated at 90,000 tonnes of raw sugar, primarily to the United States and some to Uruguay, and 40,000 tonnes of refined to Chile," the attache wrote.
"As a consequence of a lower output, supply and demand is forecast to be very tight. Therefore, we are projecting imports of approximately 70,000 tonnes, which will probably come from Brazil."
By comparison, output for marketing year 1997, which began in June, had been forecast for 1.4 million tonnes.
In marketing year 1996, output was 1.59 million tonnes with exports of 120,000 tonnes raw sugar and 50,000 tonnes refined.
Cane plantations suffered a drought during the summer. An early frost also cut into crop size.
